name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
description: Non-atherosclerotic, non-inflammatory vascular disease primarily affecting medium-sized arteries in young to middle-aged women. Characterized by 'string of beads' appearance on angiography. Most commonly involves renal and carotid/vertebral arteries.

content.statement: aku:vascular:genetic:fibromuscular-dysplasia is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Genetic-Ctd that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku:vascular:genetic:fibromuscular-dysplasia helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku:vascular:genetic:fibromuscular-dysplasia include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku:vascular:genetic:fibromuscular-dysplasia.

medial_fibroplasia.appearance: String of beads (beads LARGER than normal lumen)

diagnosis.characteristic_finding: String of beads with beads LARGER than normal lumen (medial fibroplasia)
diagnosis.screening: Screen for intracranial aneurysms in cerebrovascular FMD

carotid_fmd.symptomatic: Angioplasty or surgery for selected cases

clinical_pearls: String of beads with beads LARGER than lumen = medial fibroplasia (most common)
Young woman with hypertension = think renal FMD
PTA WITHOUT stent for renal FMD (unlike atherosclerotic disease)
Always screen for intracranial aneurysms in cerebrovascular FMD
learning_objectives: Describe the classic angiographic appearance of fibromuscular dysplasia
Explain why stenting is avoided in FMD treatment

enables.title: Renal FMD
enables.reason: Foundation for understanding most common FMD manifestation

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
